Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the mother needs to provide it
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story:
This morning, I woke up early, already feeling the weight of the day pressing on my chest. The fridge was nearly empty, and the kids’ shoes had holes in them. I needed to pick up an extra shift at the café—just enough to cover groceries and maybe a new pair of sneakers. My boss texted, asking if I could come in for a few hours. I said yes before I remembered: today is election day.

The polling station is only a few blocks away, and the polls are open all day. I know how important it is to vote, to have my voice heard for the sake of my children’s future. But the café needs me now, and so does my family. If I don’t work, we might not have enough for dinner this week. If I don’t vote, I feel like I’m letting down not just myself, but everyone who depends on the choices we make as a community.

I stare at the clock, torn between the responsibility to provide and the duty to participate. My heart pounds as I weigh what matters most, knowing that whatever I choose, something will be left undone.
